items.message:
River levels are forecasted to remain high on the Middlesbrough Becks as a result of heavy rainfall, overnight 02/08/23. Consequently, flooding of roads is possible. Areas most at risk are riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads.

Further rainfall is forecasted over the next few days. We are not expecting to issue Flood Warnings at this time.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing trash screens.

Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. To help reduce the risk of flooding in Middlesbrough, please report any blockages of trash screens to the Environment Agency as soon as possible by calling 0800 80 70 60 (24 hours).

This message will be updated by 09:00 on 03/08/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising steadily on the River Seven due to heavy rainfall today.
Flooding is possible this evening (02/08/2023) and overnight into Thursday (03/08/2023) on land around the River Seven and it's tributaries including Northdale Beck, Hartoft Beck, Ings Beck, Lastingham Beck, Sutherland Beck, Cropton Beck, Catter Beck, including properties in Sinnington and to the East of Normanby.
Further light rainfall is forecast overnight and into the rest of the week.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning (03/08/2023) or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Ings Beck, Alverthorpe Beck, Balne Beck, Oakenshaw Beck

items.message: This alert is no longer in force as the water level in Balne Beck is expected to fall through the evening and overnight. Showery outbreaks of rain on 3rd and 4th August are not expected to result in the need for further alerts in this area.

This flood alert has been issued due to high spring tides combined with high winds and some storm surge. Forecast high water is 20:15 on 02/08/23 with a level of 6.38 mAOD and a Force 5 Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. 

Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at this time, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.

The high tide on the morning of 03/08/2023 is forecast to be just below Flood Alert levels, however coastal conditions are expected to continue until after the high tides on Saturday 05/08/2023. We will update this message as necessary through the week.

This message will be updated by 12:00 on Thursday, 03/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.83mAOD at 04:30 on 03/08/23 and 4.75mAOD at 16:30 on 03/08/23.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 28 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next 2 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 18:00 on 03/08/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the West Auckland Oakley Cross river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected/possible between 14:00 and 19:00 today,  02/08/23.  Areas most at risk are riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads.

Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high until this evening on 02/08/23.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing trash screens.

Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 09:00 on 03/08/23, or as the situation changes

Thursday’s early morning tide at 00:30 on 03/08/2023 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.34 m. The total forecast tide is 5.13 metres Chart Datum (2.39 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. For 1 hour either side of high water, the tide will flood Shore Road. At Bosham High Street, water will be near to, or will flood front door steps. Gardens or land of shore side properties around the harbour could also be affected. From Thursday's afternoon high water (03/08/2023 at 13:30), tide levels and wave heights will reduce slightly and should be accompanied by lighter winds. There should be less risk of flooding from Thursday afternoon. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have them, please install flood boards 1 hour before high tide. Avoid walking through flood water as it may contain hidden hazards and be deep in places. We will update this message by 11:00 on 03/08/2023.

Thursday's early morning tide at 01:00 on 03/08/2023 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong Westerly Force 5 winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.22 m. The total forecast tide is 6.08 metres Chart Datum (3.03 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, waves could overtop the sea front, with small amounts of water affecting land and fields, and possibly properties near Climping Street Car Park. Thursday's afternoon tide and waves are predicted to be similar to recent days, potentially again generating minor flood impacts. Friday's tides should be a little lower and accompanied by smaller waves. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 11:00 on 03/08/2023.

There is a possibility of flooding for Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon. Sea spray overtopping along the coast and high water levels in the harbour are forecast as a result of high spring tides. The forecast high water is at 21:57 Wednesday, 02/08/23 with a level of 1.33 mAOD with Force 5 Westerley winds.

mAOD is height above average sea level. The low pressure can cause sea levels to be higher than forecast in these tide.

Flooding to roads and low lying land is possible and conditions can apply one to two hours either side of high tide. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

This message will be updated 03/08/23, or as the situation changes.

Flood alert area: Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
There is a possibility of flooding for Poole Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Frome and Piddle, particularly at Wareham. High water levels are forecast as a result of high spring tides. The forecast high water is 21:45 Wednesday, 02/08/23 with a level of 1.34 mAOD with Force 5 Westerly winds. Low pressure can cause sea levels to be higher than forecast in these tides.

Flooding to roads and low lying land is possible and conditions can apply one to two hours either side of high tide. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

This message will be updated 03/08/2023 or as the situation changes.

Flood alert area: Poole Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Frome and River Piddle.

Thursday's early morning tide at 00:20 on 03/08/2023 and 02:32 on 03/08/2023 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with light South Westerly Force 3 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.5 m. The total forecast tide is 4.20 metres Chart Datum (2.20 mAOD) at Beaulieu. For 30 minutes either side of high water, the tide will flood into the garden of the mill house on the downstream side of the Mill Pond. Minor road flooding at Palace Lane is also expected, making access to the village temporarily more difficult. After this tide‚ the weather becomes more settled‚ so levels will reduce and no further impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. For safety, please take care if walking or driving through Beaulieu. The incoming tide will flood the main road quickly. We will remove this message by 09:00 on 03/08/2023.
Tide levels will remain high over the next 24hrs. Until then, at each high water, very minor impacts may be experienced, but we do not expect the tide to affect major roads or property.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: Strong winds and spring tides are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning. Areas most at risk include the Southfield farm coast, Kilnsea caravan park and Spurn road. Flooding is expected at The North Sea coast from Mappleton to Spurn Point between 05:45 AM and 09:00 AM on 03/08/2023. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 03/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal flooding of areas near the Lincolnshire coastline
items.message: The risk of flooding from the high tide has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

The forecast weather conditions during spring tides, means that high tides are expected  between 6am and 10am tomorrow morning, Thursday 3 August.  Areas most at risk are around Hunstanton seafront. 

Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority which will make access difficult.

The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of  4.45mAODN at 08:00am, on Thursday 3 August, which is 0.38m above tide tables, wind Force 5, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  The following tide on Thursday at 09:00pm is currently forecast to be below the Alert threshold.

Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Thursday 3rd August.

items.description: Coast from Heacham to north of King's Lynn in Norfolk
items.message:
The forecast weather conditions during spring tides, means that high tides are expected  between 6am and 10am tomorrow morning, Thursday 3rd August.  Areas most at risk are Heacham, Snettisham, Ingoldisthorpe, Dersingham and Wolferton.  

The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of 4.45mAODN at 08:00am, on Thursday 3 August, which is 0.38m above tide tables, wind Force 5, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  The following tide on Thursday at 09:00pm is currently forecast to be below the Alert threshold.
Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Thursday 3rd August.

As a result of high spring tides and strong winds we are expecting large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning.

Consequently, flooding of roads is possible on the high tides at 05:00 tomorrow and 07:00 tomorrow, 03/08/23.  Areas most at risk are beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads   

Coastal conditions are expected to continue over the next few days as we are in a period of spring tides. This Flood Alert will remain in force or be re-issued as needed.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens.

Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated  by 10:00 on 03/08/23, or as the situation changes.

There is a possibility of flooding for West Bay Harbour and the tidal stretch of the River Brit. Sea spray overtopping along the coast and high water levels are forecast as a result of high spring tides. The forecast high water is at 19:15 Wednesday, 02/08/23 with a level of 2.19 mAOD, with Force 6 Westerley winds.

mAOD is height above average sea level. The low pressure can cause sea levels to be higher than forecast in these tide.

Flooding to roads and low lying land is possible, and conditions can apply one to two hours either side of high tide. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

This message will be updated 03/08/23, or as the situation changes.

Flood alert area: West Bay Harbour and the tidal stretch of the River Brit

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 01:00 PM on 03/08/2023.
Areas most at risk include the coast from Ramsgate to Kingsdown and low lying land along the tidal River Stour. 
Flooding is possible at coastal areas, particularly low lying land and roads nearest the sea between 11:00 AM and 03:00 PM on 03/08/2023. No property flooding is expected at this point.
Strong winds and surge are forecast over the next four days. We are expecting higher than normal tides and as a result we may issue further alerts.
We are closely monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 03/08/2023, or as the situation changes.
For those that use it, the astronomical level will be 3.22mAOD and the total water level will be 3.62mAOD.

items.description: Coast from St Margaret's at Cliffe to Sandgate
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 01:00 PM on 03/08/2023.
Areas most at risk include the coast from St Margaret's at Cliffe to Sandgate.
Flooding is possible at coastal areas, particularly low lying land and roads nearest the sea between 11:00 AM and 03:00 PM on 03/08/2023. No property flooding is expected at this point.
Strong winds and surge are forecast over the next four days. We are expecting higher than normal tides and as a result we may issue further alerts.
We are closely monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 03/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Isle of Sheppey and coast from Kemsley to Seasalter
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide expected tomorrow morning, Thursday 03/08/2023, as a result of high spring tides and strong winds.  Tides will be at their highest between 00:00 and 04:00 am tomorrow, 03/08/2023, with high tide expected at 02:00. We expect flooding to affect low lying land, promenades and coastal footpaths.   
The unsettled weather and high spring tides are expected to continue over the coming days, with periods of flooding possible. We will issue further messages if required.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.  
For those that need it, the forecast total water level for Sheerness is forecast to be 3.50m AOD at 02:00 tomorrow 03/08/2023.
This message will be updated by 08:00 tomorrow, 03/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely, due to an unseasonal low pressure system causing a small surge between 12:30am and 2:30am on Thursday 3rd August. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded. Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.6mAODN at 1:30am on Thursday 3rd August, which is 0.39m above tide tables, wind force 6, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). The following tide on Thursday 3rd August at 1:45pm is also currently forecast to be a Flood Alert and we will update this message before that tide. You are advised to stay away from at risk areas and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 9:00am tomorrow, Thursday 3rd August.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.message:
Flooding is possible this afternoon and overnight tonight, Wednesday 02 August. 

The heavy rain which fell earlier today has caused river levels to rise. This may result in flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers through the rest of this afternoon and overnight into Thursday morning. However, flooding to properties is not currently expected. 

Heavy showers are forecast to continue and we expect river levels to remain high throughout the rest of today and overnight. 

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Thursday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely to occur between 01:00am and 03:00am tomorrow, Thursday 3rd August. This is due to an unseasonal low pressure system causing a small tidal surge. Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low lying land between the fort and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.59mAODN at 02:00am, Thursday 3rd August, which is 0.39m above tide tables, wind Force 5, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). You are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. The following tide, on Thursday 3rd August at 2:15pm, is also currently forecast to be a Flood Alert. We will update this message before that tide.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely, due to an unseasonal low pressure system causing a small surge between 12.30am and 2:30am on Thursday 3rd August. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.6mAODN at 1:30am on Thursday 3rd August, which is 0.39m above tide tables, wind force 6, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). The following tide on Thursday 3rd August at 1:45pm is also currently forecast to be a Flood Alert, and we will update this message before that tide. You are advised to stay away from at risk areas and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 9:00am tomorrow, Thursday 3rd August.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely, due to an unseasonal low pressure system causing a small surge between 12:30am and 2:30am on Thursday 3rd August. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.78mAODN at 1:30am on Thursday 3rd August, which is 0.33m above tide tables, wind force 6, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). The following tide on Thursday 3rd August at 1:45pm is also currently forecast to be a Flood Alert and we will update this message before that tide. You are advised to stay away from at risk areas and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 9:00am tomorrow, Thursday 3rd August.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Somerset, Wiltshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: Somerset Frome, River Mells, Whatley Brook, Nunney Brook

items.message:
River levels are rising on the Somerset Frome especially River Mells and Whatley Brook due to heavy rainfall. River levels are not currently forecast to reach to reach flood warning level.

Areas most at risk include Feltham Lane at Frome, the A362 at Wallbridge, the access road to Peradins at Freshford and the Westwood to Freshford road. Further areas at risk include Farleigh Hungerford, Nunney, Vobster and Spring Gardens near Frome.

We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 03/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely to occur tomorrow morning, Thursday 3rd August, between 07:00am and 09:00am. This is due to an unseasonal low pressure system causing a small tidal surge. We expect to see water on roads and paths to beaches, and on the quays in Brancaster, Burnham Overy, Holkham, Wells and Blakeney. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.70mAODN at 08:00am, Thursday 3rd August, which is 0.52m above tide tables, wind Force 6, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The following tide, at 9:00pm on Thursday 3rd August, is not currently forecast to reach Flood Alert level. You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10:00am tomorrow, Thursday 3rd August.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from East Cley to Kelling Hard, including Salthouse
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely to occur between 07:00am and 09:00am, tomorrow morning, Thursday 3rd August. This is due to an unseasonal low pressure system causing a small tidal surge. We may see water on Beach Road at Cley, and Beach Road at Salthouse. Footpaths in the marshes may also become inaccessible. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.70mAODN at 08:00am, Thursday 3rd August, which is 0.52m above tide tables, wind Force 6, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). The following tide, at 9:00pm on Thursday 3rd August, is not currently forecast to reach Flood Alert level. You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10:00am tomorrow, Thursday 3rd August.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning (03/08/23). Areas most at risk include The North Sea coast from Skipsea to Mappleton, including Hornsea between 04:45 AM and 08:30 AM on 03/08/2023. High astronomical tides will continue over the next few days peaking on Saturday. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 03/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message: Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning. Areas most at risk are Marine Drive, along South Promenade, Hornsea Burton Road and along Stream Dike and Foss Beck between 04:45 AM and 08:30 AM on 03/08/2023. High astronomical tides will continue over the next few days peaking on Saturday 05/08/2023. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. Start acting on your flood plan if you have on. Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous.  This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 03/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected between 16:50 and 21:00 today, 02/08/2023.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Shuttle particularly in and around Willersley Avenue.   
  We expect river levels to remain high until 21:00 today, 02/08/2023. 
Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required..  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated  by 08:00 on 03/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from the Thames Barrier to Putney Bridge
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: City of London, Greater London, Greenwich, Hammersmith and Fulham, Kensington and Chelsea, Lambeth, Lewisham, Newham, Southwark, Tower Hamlets, Wandsworth, Westminster

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at London Bridge is 4.55mAOD at 03:30 on 03/08/23.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Custom House (EC3R), Narrow Street (E14), Mayflower and Angel pubs (SE16), Royal Naval College riverfront, the Almshouse Slipway at Crane Street (SE10), Bankside by the Tate Modern (SE1), and Three Mill Island (E3).

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 28 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next 2 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 03/08/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Norfolk coast from Bacton to Ostend, including Walcott
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely to occur tomorrow morning, due to an unseasonal low pressure system causing a small surge, between 07:15am and 09:15am on Thursday 3rd August. The Coast Road at Walcott may see some wave overtopping and spray. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Cromer of 3.11mAODN at 8:15am on Thursday 3rd August, which is 0.62m above tide tables, wind force 6, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). The following high tide at 9:00pm on Thursday 3rd August is not expected to reach Flood Alert level. You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10:00am tomorrow, Thursday 3rd August.

items.description: The Norfolk coast from Eccles on Sea, to and including, Winterton-on-Sea
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely to occur tomorrow morning, due to an unseasonal low pressure system causing a small surge between 7:15am and 9:15am on Thursday 3rd August. High tides mean flood gates will be closed restricting normal access to beaches around Eccles on Sea and Sea Palling. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Cromer of 3.11mAODN at 8:15am on Thursday 3rd August, which is 0.62m above tide tables, wind force 6, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). The following high tide at 9:00pm on Thursday 3rd August is not expected to reach Flood Alert level. You are advised to stay away from at risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10:00am tomorrow, Thursday 3rd August.

items.description: The Suffolk coast from Lowestoft to Bawdsey
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely to occur between 10:00am and 12:00 midday tomorrow, Thursday 3rd August. This is due to an unseasonal low pressure system causing a small tidal surge. We expect to see high water levels in Lake Lothing in Lowestoft, as well as high sea levels along the Suffolk Coast, impacting on beach access points. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 1.81mAODN at 11:00am, Thursday 3rd August, which is 0.62m above tide tables, wind Force 6, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. The following tide, at 00:00 midnight into Friday 4th August, is not currently forecast to reach Flood Alert level. We will update this message by 2:00pm tomorrow, Thursday 3rd August.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely to occur between 10:00am and 12:00 midday tomorrow, Thursday 3rd August. This is due to an unseasonal low pressure system causing a small tidal surge. We expect high tide levels at the harbourside in Southwold. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 1.81mAODN at 11:00am, Thursday 3rd August, which is 0.62m above tide tables, wind Force 6, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. The following tide at 00:00 midnight, Friday 4th August, is not currently forecast to reach Flood Alert level. We will update this message by 2:00pm tomorrow, Thursday 3rd August.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast during the high tide forecast at 05:30 AM and 09:30 AM on 03/08/2023. Areas most at risk include Kilnsea coast. Waves are forecast to overtop coastal defences at The Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. This message will be updated by 10 am 03/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising steadily on the River Foss due to heavy rainfall today. Flooding is possible overnight into Thursday (03/08/2023) on low lying land and roads. Areas most at risk are around the River Foss upstream of Yearsley Baths to Strensall. Further light rainfall is forecast overnight and into the rest of the week. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated in the morning, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: River levels are rising steadily on the Upper River Derwent due to recent heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk include low lying land, roads and footpaths in the Upper Derwent between Mowthorpe and West Ayton. Flooding is possible overnight into Thursday morning 03/08/2023. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning (03/08/23) or as the situation changes.
